content.rendered:
Wow. For decades I’ve struggled to really understand this song and what’s it’s all about. It’s all been a mystery to me and I’ve never really been able to connect with it. I never got what they were hiding from. This analysis is truly eye-opening. Who knows if it’s true or not, but this really makes a lot of sense. I feel like you just revealed the truth behind this song. With the secret out, the lyrics and the whole song just jumped to another level in my book. The meaning of the song is no longer hiding from me, on the backstreets or on the beach at Stockton’s Wing or anywhere else. Thanks for this gift, from a longtime Bruce fan.

P.S. I always lamented that Suki and her violin left. That performance of Incident on 2/5/75 haunts me. For decades, Jungleland was never the same, until Soozie joined up.
Bring it, Katy!
You are very convincing re: the affair and its connection to “Backstreets,” but I am scribbling my “Terry is still a dude” response in my head as I read it. Stay tuned!

Great analysis of the song. It’s fun and challenging to tear apart a song like this (I tackled Thunder Road awhile back). As for Suki, she wasn’t even mentioned in Bruce’s book. But then there were lots of things he didn’t cover.

I have listened to this song hundreds if not thousands of times, always appreciating its raw power, but never really solving the lyrical puzzle in my mind. Marsh’s take in Born to Run confused me, and I always found the lyrics opaque. After reading Ken’s exposition I feel like a lock has been picked, and many of the mysteries of the lyrics and the story are opened at last. As I head out the door this morning, I am going to put Backstreets on the headphones and, after decades of listening to this moving song in so many iterations, hear it anew for the first time. Feel like a broken record (itself an ironic phrase) in my posting comments, but thank you so much Ken!
Thank you for this. Your site is so rich in detail!
What about Karon Bihari? There was an article about her in The National Enquirer saying she was Candy. Yes, I know…The Enquirer. But she sounds believable.
What a gift. Thanks so much.

Keep your fantastic job going, Ken!
I love your website and blogs❤️
I think you’ve done an amazing job, full stop!!!! Thank you….
Great site! I learn a lot! Thanks

The best. What you do is awesome, appreciated and brings me back to my first listen to Born to Run while a student at Camden County College, Blackwood NJ. Remember by Accounting 101 teacher talking about the concert the morning after Bruce played (Sadly, I had to work that night).
Ken, thank you — your work is a gift. Take your time, no need to hurry.

Hi Ken, I am one of those who hardly ever comments on blogs. Your blog is a ray of sunshine, and I will continue to appreciate it even if it is a bit less frequent. Your perspectives and commentary have very much resonated with me. I have learned and thought about Bruce’s music in different ways as a result of your blog. Please enjoy life and do know that you are greatly valued by your readers.

I love your posts and insights even if I don’t always agree. Lol. I want to thank you for your untiring efforts and even if it was to become once a week, I would still look forward to it with excitement
Keep up the good work
I don’t comment often, but just letting you know how much I enjoy visiting this blog and receiving the emails. Have a great summer!
This email just made me smile. Thankful for whatever and whenever you are able to keep posting. We need more such happiness in the world.
Thank you for what you do, so beautifully — please keep it coming, and as frequently (or not) as you see fit— we’ll be here!
Thank you!

Don’t sell yourself short my friend! Your Daily Post bring a lot of entertainment. joy and good reading. I’m sure I’m not alone when I say that super fans of Bruce like myself going on 200 shows for the last 45 years could never get enough of this. Congratulations on some of your exciting life events and keep on rocking🎵🎷🎸

Thanks for everything.
You are not taking for granted.
I so appreciate your work, and also that you are practicing some self-care.
Your work is appreciated and enjoyed, no matter if it’s daily, every other day or whatever the schedule. I consider it a gift from you. Thank you, thank you!!
I love your work and enjoy every word, photo and video. Life rules. I hope to meet you one day, so until then, thank you for all of it!

What? You have a life outside of Bruce? Outrageous!

Seriously, we really appreciate you and your efforts and will continue to with your new schedule. Enjoy that grandbaby!

I enjoy your posts and look forward to all of them. I appreciate your hard work, insights/analysis and dedication to what you do for us out here in E Street Nation. I fully support you doing whatever you need & want and I’ll keep looking forward to your posts. Thank you, thank you, thank you!!!🙌🏽🙏🏽
Appreciate everything you publish, obviously also understand that you do actually have a life outside this. Publish when you can, I for one will be grateful.
you deserve a break!! thanks for the effort, always a good way to start my day.

I want to ditto what Craig said. Take the time you need for the great content we keep coming back for! And, of course, just take the time in general if you need it. Thanks for making the best blog I read.

Really appreciate your huge effort and generally read all your posts. You have an engaging writing style and obviously a great depth of knowledge, not only of Bruce, but all of the music, trivia and just interesting snippets that contribute to his music and songwriting. Thank you
Very very grateful for all you do. Thank you…whatever schedule works for you is a blessing for us!

Hey Jesse – Yes! That would have been great to connect with you and Ken after the show. Actually, on 5-6-2014, I didn’t know who Jesse Jackson and Ken Rosen were. Now, both of you are “household names” and huge contributors to the Bruce and E Street community. I am so grateful I’ve been able to connect with you both virtually over the past 8 years. Rob Carmack from Bruce Springsteen Sings The Alphabet was at this show also.

Still one of my favorite shows and now that I know that both Ken and Jon were at the show, I wish we could have all gone some where afterwards for a drink and a show recap. I’m still bitter that I didn’t get This is your Sword but I’m sure any year now, I’ll get over it.
You mean, “You know that isn’t really him interviewing Springsteen, right? That’s the joke, just as the Brilliant Disguise video isn’t an alternate cut with Al trying to put Bruce off.
You… know that isn’t REALLY him interviewing Weird Al, right? That’s an interview with someone else and Al just added himself in.
Hoot!

“Pete, we can do anything,” I (Richard Barone) blurted: Fantastic MATR. Loved the 25 minute Scott Pelley interview with Mike Williams (survivor of the BP Deepwater Horizon disaster) and Dr. Bee. Also loved the fantastic video shoot aboard the sloop Clearwater–“When we work with younger folks, we can never give up hope!” Interesting that Bruce’s involvement with Appleseed interrupted the process that Pete and Richard Barone hoped for. (Wonder how Bruce felt about this?) I must say, I prefer the sloop Clearwater version of “God’s Counting On Me..” I had no idea about the disaster or the indie artist Richard Barone until this MATR. Thanks for the deep research, inspiration and recommended reading. “What we do now, you and me, will affect eternity.” (You hit it out of the ball park, Ken.)
a poured out drink in the dirt for a past love or a fallen comrade is called a Libation.

I had it on my Walkman through some dark tough times in the early 1980s and it’s a great album. His words have great literary merit and there is no shame in analysing them as such. I still hear it as *the* promised land that he desperately hopes will exist to explain things to the striver in the unfair struggle for freedom. There is not really a secular analogue as you imply. There are numerous musings on faith and it’s nature , secular. Biblical or otherwise in his other songs. He is a great admirer of Dylan and although as far as I am aware he hasn’t personally shared any observations on his his own faith he does appear to approach faith with a questioning tone. I think “Reason to believe” is probably most telling in his secular attitude towards the nature of faith. I still hear it as The Promised Land which is it’s title. But he’s asking , Am I wrong?

Funny that today’s Roll of the Dice is about “I wanna marry you.” because I’ve been singing the song all day and wondering about some of the same lyrics writeen about in this article, I always thought that this song is a fantasy crush by a guy who used to see pretty girls walking by him at work. Maybe a guy working a hot dog joint on the boardwalk or managin an arcade at the Jersey Shore. Seeing a steady flow of pretty girls day after day. Is it Bruce at his finest, maybe not, his greatest. But its the kind of a story that the average guy can relate too!

Excellent research on “Chains” and Beatle George”. His vocals on both the BBC and official recording are great! Also, am not sure I’ve heard Bruce’s (Steel Mill?) version until now. Great as well. Wonder who shared the first singing solo with Bruce? Bruce sounds fantastic on the second solo vocal and throughout with the harmonies. Nice lead guitar work from Bruce as well on the 8′ recording. A fun “Cover Me”!
fabulous rarity among rarities – thanks!

Yes I saw this right away too. To my knowledge he has never actually played left handed on stage..Bizarre! The sequence is definitely from the official “Born to Run” video from the 80s – everything the same except he’s playing left handed. what gives?
Video is very clever; wonder if Bruce playing left-handed is intentional?
Wow! I didn’t know the back story to Roulette. Thanks Ken for another educational and entertaining post. The San Siro live version is powerful!!

Ken, I loved that you featured this on MATR. Such a great song, and I’ll argue that rock music reaches its zenith when it elevates the reckless abandon and fun of life into something like this. My feeling is that the January 1981 performance at Notre Dame was the pinnacle; Clarence’s solo, the a cappella verse, and most of all the rabid crowd response and participation is pure joy and took the song beyond even the original artists’ conception. I had an old cassette bootleg of that show and listened to this song in particular over and over during my college years. Thank you so much for highlighting it today!

According to Brucebase, he did soundcheck this song once on the Reunion Tour before his second show at The Palace of Auburn Hills on 9/9/99. Not sure if there’s a recording of it, but would be fun to hear! 😊

This is probably my favorite cover of BITUSA. I appreciate their decision to stick closer to the demo as opposed to the E Street version. Wife and I were fortunate to see Jason with the 400 Unit last summer (unfortunately, Amanda had fallen ill the night before), and they were phenomenal. When folks complain to me about “today’s music”, I point to Jason Isbell (among others), for proof that music is doing just fine. Thanks for posting!

Underrated song, in the sense that I think it’s very powerful but most of the discussion I’ve read of it over the years was how much people hate the song’s sound and mix. I always thought the vocals were intentionally buried in the music, sort of yelling from a mass of noise, not a mistake or error.
He’s not saying “walk away” in the sense of walking away from something. The “away” means freely, without care. As in “sing away” later in the song.
I love this song. I’ve never quite understood the “walk away” part of the lyrics. What are your thoughts?
This was my first Springsteen concert! I was so happy to see local musician Don Henley join him on stage! Thanks for the memories!
This was a family favorite back in the days when I drove the kids to school. It brought us joy to be singing along with Bruce and the band!
This is very timely for today because Pope Francis has invited all bishops to join him in an Act of Consecration of Ukraine and Russia to the Immaculate Heart of Mary
Ken – Just a random musing from your comment above and this cover…It would be interesting if Bruce went back to TGOTJ and arranged all the songs like Western Skies…
Such an underrated song. Great cover!
I was at the show and still remember a spotlight shining on an empty stool with a sax in a stand. Very moving… When it came time for a solo, Bruce brought Jake out like a big brother would.
Had the privilege of seeing this song in Cardiff.it nearly took the stadium roof off!
Thanks for that wise look at a great piece of art.

Wow, beautiful writings, Ken. I have always loved this song and related from the female side of things with my mother. It took a long time before a truce could be reached. In the time in between there was so much sadness.
So nice to meet you this past weekend!
Great insights, Timmy! Thanks for sharing them and for reading!

I recently discovered your site, and love reading the various analyses of the songs and made me see some things in a new light – never made the connection between Darlington County and Delivery Man, for example.

As for this one, it’s actually one of my favorites off the Magic album, though it’s really a great album so it’s in hard competition. I held up a sign for it during the 2008 Magic concerts here in Sweden and Bruce noticed it but just said “haven’t rehearsed that one” or something like that.

My personal analyis of the song is a bit more specific; couldn’t it be a comment on the post-2000’s music industry? I’m getting a lot of American Idol vibes from the lines like “they’ll use you up and spit you out”, “you’ll be fine long as your pretty face holds out”, and “an empty stream of stars shootin’ by” is great wordplay. So instead of it being about the ups and downs of life, it’s about someone who is in the middle of their 15 minutes of fame, but will eventually have to come down to reality when their record company ditches them to move on to promote someone younger and more popular.
I think you might be able to do it from SoundCloud if you follow the link in the article.

Hey Ken

Do you have a link where I can download “Springsteen”?
Thank you!

Ken:
Brilliant piece of writing.
Thank you for all your amazing work!
What town did you grow up in, Bud?

This is one of his songs that hits home for me in the same ways. I grew up in NJ and my dad worked at a plant, I was the oldest son and left home for college 1,000 miles away and only went back to visit. My dad, brother and sisters still live there – the plant closed several years ago and the town is struggling.
Some of Dion’s Chrisitan music actually did chart/award
In his autobiography, I remember Paul Stanley from Kiss, saying how he loved the song and how his song Shandi was a not so well hidden homage to Sandy.
”And if it had to perish twice.”
”Because there will be moments.”

Ooø ; what do you know.

But he doesn’t sing Linden Town, does he? What does he say?
For part 5 (LOL) … https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YluWV20TT5Y

Wow! Had not seen the “Love and Mercy” video or the incredible footage of Bruce singing background with Brian’s band in ’87. One could clearly sense Bruce was honored and humbled to be in Brian’s presence and singing this beautiful song. A timely MATR!

Brian Wilson was my first musical obsession. God Only Knows, Wouldn’t it be Nice, I just wasn’t made for these Times, California Girls, I get Around, Good Vibrations, the list goes on and on but there is something special about Love and Mercy. Hearing the song clip above brought me to tears this morning and I’m crying as I type this.

“I was lyin’ in my room and the news came on t.v.
A lotta people out there hurtin’ and it really scares me
Love and mercy that’s what you need tonight
So, love and mercy to you and your friends tonight”

Amen Brian, Amen!
A fun song to play too. Lots of layers in there. Like any great 1-4-5, lots of room to play around with it, lots of different moods to bring to it.

This is a great article. I didn’t even know about the Hank Williams song, philistine that I am.

I really thought the reunion tour version completely reversed the very meaning of the song, which was really cool. It was do-able without changing a single word.

Then again I hadn’t thought of the ambiguity that the lyrics allowed for all along, as you mentioned here with the last verse.

Aw, I have to respectfully disagree about Rainmaker not fitting LTY’s themes. It does stand out, and I’m sure that the timing is the main reason Bruce added it, but it still discusses love and trust in very spiritual terms (makes me think of the “blind faith in your leaders…” comment). Musically it’s also got similarities with BITUSA and that was a pretty important era that imo isn’t really represented anywhere else in the album!

Much enjoyed your comparisons (and distinctions) between Hank’s and Bruce’s vision of their respective “Mansion On The Hill”: As written, “{It is} impossible to listen to Hank’s and Bruce’s recordings and not hear the other reflected…both employ the mansion as metaphor for a life that seems unattainable to their narrators.” “As I sit here alone in my cabin, I can see your mansion on the hill” and “At night my daddy’d take me and we’d ride…look up at that mansion on the hill.” Wow! Also, loved the included videos of seeing, once again, Danny on the accordion and Nils on guitar and lap steel; not to mention the Bruce/Patti yodel and beautiful harmony–channeling “Johnny and June”–from Live In New York. Another great “Roll”, again, crystalizing a stunning display of song writing.
Thank you Ken, this is excellent. My wife is Ukrainian and has been prominent in raising funds in Wales. Let us hope Ukraine can beat the evil Putin

Reading and listening I was just about to say I heard another familiar song through the bars, as if there was another one locked up in there. And then right there you spelled that out. Absolutely marvelous track, with just a little nudge too much ”genre” to it.

Yeah!! thanks again 4ur lessons and reccomands 4all ur generously info u post..good job m8 ur team2 !! Yeah feel so glad !! best reggards from Isla de Mallorca..pleased 2ve found u !! I apreciate so much ur daily lessons u posr !! thanks Ken

Interesting comment in the Paul Williams interview from October 13, 1974: “See, I never had a record player for years and years. It was a space from when my parents moved out west and I started to live by myself, from when I was seventeen until I was twenty-four, and I never had a record player. So It was like I never heard any albums that came out ofter, like ’67 [laughs]. And I was never a social person who went over to other’s people’s housed and got loaded and listened to records — I nver did that. And I didn’t have an FM radio, so I never heard anything, From that time on, from around ’67 until just recently when I got a record player, I lived wiht Diane [Rosito] and she had an old beat-up one that only old records sounded good on. So that’s all I played. Those old Fats Domino records, they sounded great on it.
Cover Ukraine! No surrender! You’re right, Ken! The timing is perfect

Wait, so this is Bruce’s 2010 voice? I’m usually quick to pick up on that type of stuff, or so I thought. Jeez, they did a pretty good job on this one. “Meet Me in the City” was much more obviously his modern voice, for example.

Each time I think of songs like “There Goes My Miracle” and “Sundown” as being totally not Bruce, I remember some of the songs from this era and remember the range he always had. Not that they’re totally alike, but…

Ken, I have a random, semi-related question for you. I love the song “Stray Bullet.” But something tells me there is absolutely no way the guitar sound at the end is from that era. It sounds like Tom Morello or maybe Nils. Am I right?
Thanks. First time hearing this. Bruce is at 1:58, for sure. He may be elsewhere, but clear as day at 1:58.

Once you pick his voice out he’s quite hard to unhear! I recommend listening out for him in “hold out Martha, help is surely on its way”, “there’s no master” and “you know the truth’s been made a crutch”, I think those are the lines where he’s the most prominent.
This is one of my favorite albums and my favorite part of this song is the missed beat!
why don’t Bruce-Landau Inc release one of those shows as part of the archive series???? It’s definitely part of the E Street legacy
Cool! Never saw this before. Am I hearing a little of Human Touch in the music?
This was “electric!” Wow! I saw Garry and Roy playing and did I see Danny?

Clarence’s sax solo indeed add another dimension to this Dylan masterpiece and E Street harmonies are nice in the above soundcheck. Also, love the deeply authentic vocals of Bob and Rick Dango in the various versions.

I’m slowly but surely (finally!) getting into Dylan’s music and this is one of my favourite song ‘discoveries’ of his so far. I had no idea Bruce and the Band soundchecked it, thanks for bringing it to my attention, Ken!

A very important “Roll”. After reading your insightful review I tend to believe both: It is a “sex romp” but also social commentary, perhaps to justify Bruce’s personal demons that haunted him during his personal infidelity of 1987 and ’88. There’s no question Bruce had a deep “edge” during the Tunnel tour. “Part Man” was most often followed by “Walk Like A Man” on that tour, seeming to balance the emotional/moral fight within. But then again, you may be right as Bruce implores, “Sylvia, how do you call your lover boy?” “Her” arousing response follows, “Baby. Oh Baby! Oh Baby! You’re the One!”

Bruce…launching into an extended jam that’s twice as long as the album track. (KR)

“I had my good-eye to the dark-
Ride That Train!” (Bruce)…”Ride That Train!” (choir)

“I had my good-eye to the dark-
Ride That Train!”…”Ride That Train” (choir)

“Get Your Ticket, There!-
Ride That Train!”…”Ride That Train!” (choir)

“Get Your Ticket, There!-
Ride That Train!”

Wow!

(“Good Eye” is as bluesy as rock and roll gets.
San Jose, 4.1.09)
